title: Yelp CFO to Exit for Eventbrite
summary: Online-review company needs a CFO that can foster stability, analysts say. Yelp Inc.'s finance chief is leaving as the online-review company seeks to reach a broader audience.

title: Uber Posts Its Largest Quarterly Loss
summary: Hefty expense related to its IPO weighs on earnings as revenue rises 14%. Uber Technologies Inc. recorded its largest-ever quarterly loss as it was weighed down by heavy competition in Latin America and elsewhere, as well as a big expense related to its initial public offering.

title: Longtime Broadway Press Agent Bob Ullman Dies at 97
summary: 'He could tell you the name of the third chorus member from the left as recently as last year'. A couple of weeks before he died, Robert "Bob" Ullman told a friend he was ready for his final curtain call.

title: Uncle Trump to the Naval Rescue
summary: Europe claims it can't rely on the U.S., but look who's protecting ships.. Well, well, look who's coming to the rescue of the British and shipping in the Middle East. None other than the Trump Administration that is supposed to be an unreliable ally. The Brits now say they're joining a U.S.-led coalition to protect merchant shipping after they failed to get help from the rest of Europe.

title: Activision Results Hurt by Lack of New Games
summary: Videogame maker leaned on content updates, special events for existing franchises. Activision Blizzard Inc.'s revenue fell nearly 15% in the second quarter, hurt by the videogame maker again not releasing any major new games during the period.

title: News Corp Revenue Falls 8% in Quarter
summary: At media company's news and information-services business, revenue sank 5%, with ad revenue down 8%. News Corp reported an 8% decline in revenue for the June quarter, reflecting lower sales at its book-publishing unit, lower advertising revenue at its news and information-services business and the negative impact of foreign-currency fluctuations.

title: Crime and Non-Punishment in NYC
summary: A case study in the cost of abandoning 'broken-windows' policing.. New Yorkers who have arrived in the two decades since Rudy Giuliani cleaned up the streets take for granted that they can comfortably take a subway late at night. But for how much longer? Public order is eroding as the city's progressive leaders have slammed the brakes on "broken-windows" policing.

title: Another Day in Bureaucratic Hell
summary: A legal fight with the EPA shows the worst of the administrative state.. Modern bureaucratic government can sometimes be difficult to navigate. But this summer a federal appeals court in Washington, D.C., issued a ruling on the administrative state that would make Kafka smile.

title: New Risk Guidance Being Developed for Cybersecurity, Compliance
summary: Key standard-setter on internal controls expects to issue a set of guidelines later this year. A key standard-setter on internal controls is preparing to publish a set of guidelines for companies on how to manage cybersecurity and other enterprise risks.

title: Facebook Makes Offer to News Outlets to License Content
summary: Company approached ABC News, Dow Jones, Washington Post and Bloomberg as it plans to launch news section. Facebook Inc. is offering news outlets millions of dollars for the rights to put their content in a news section that the company hopes to launch later this year, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Stock Price-Related Impairment Charges Expected to Rise as Markets Fluctuate
summary: Kraft Heinz booked a $474 million charge in relation to the decline in its stock price. More companies are to follow, impairment analysts say. Stock price-related impairment charges such as the one booked Thursday by Kraft Heinz Co. are expected to increase amid ongoing market turbulence and an uncertain economic outlook.

title: NYC Considers Rezoning for Admission to Some Brooklyn Schools
summary: Education department seeks solution to crowded and segregated elementary schools. New York City officials are floating ideas for rezoning admissions for seven public elementary schools in Brooklyn, in an effort to relieve overcrowding in sought-after schools and foster integration.

title: McCabe Sues Justice Department Over Firing
summary: Ex-deputy FBI director says Trump administration terminated him last year for political reasons. Former Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe, whom the Trump administration fired on the eve of his retirement last year, sued the Justice Department, claiming his termination was unlawful and driven by a political plot to oust those viewed as disloyal to President Trump.

title: Streaming Services Boost CBS Revenue
summary: Media giant's second-quarter profit rose 10% to $440 million, or $1.17 a share. CBS Corp.'s investment in content and streaming-services expansion helped deliver better-than-expected revenue growth in its second quarter.

title: FedEx-Amazon Split Will Provide a Shipment Windfall for Rivals
summary: Delivery experts say package operators including the Postal Service will have capacity to handle surge before the holidays. FedEx Corp.'s split with Amazon.com Inc. is expected to deliver a holiday e-commerce boost to rival United Parcel Service Inc., the U.S. Postal Service and regional package carriers as other providers pick up the slack.

title: Google Adds Tools to Attract More Corporate Customers
summary: Many of the new features make use of AI, including a security tool for Google Drive. Google continues to ramp up efforts to add business-friendly features to G Suite, its set of email, productivity and collaboration tools, as it seeks to draw more commercial customers. Many of the new features include capabilities powered by artificial intelligence.

title: 'One Child Nation' Review: Ghost Generations
summary: Nanfu Wang's documentary investigates the terrible toll taken by China's decades-long campaign of population control.. Some documentaries achieve distinction through clear-cut cause and effect-they bring recognition to worthy subjects, or cause grief for deserving scoundrels. But what of a film that depicts the almost inconceivable horrors of an event in the past? What effect can it have now? The subject of "One Child Nation" is the draconian campaign of population control that convulsed China between 1979 and 2015 by limiting families to one child. A strong rationale for this devastating-and distinguished-documentary feature comes from one of its most eloquent participants, an artist named Peng Wang. He has used the one-child policy as a recurring theme in his work to help preserve in the national memory an infamous period that is being expunged from the public record. The film does that and more, both as oral history and as exemplary investigative journalism.

title: 'The Peanut Butter Falcon' Review: A Beguiling Buddy Tale
summary: A young man with Down syndrome escapes from his nursing home and strikes up a friendship with a small-time crook-played by Shia LaBeouf-in this charmingly off-kilter film.. The hero of "The Peanut Butter Falcon" wants to be a hero in his own life story but doesn't think he qualifies because, as he says at one point, "I am a Down syndrome." That's poignant, as well as misleadingly incomplete: Zak (Zack Gottsagen), the less articulate half of what turns out to be a buddy tale, knows he's much more than a syndrome, and often says so in no uncertain terms. It's also the only bit of poignancy in a comedy adventure that has no use for the stuff, any more than it does for naked tenderness, disability sentimentality or full-frontal sweetness. This lovely debut feature by Tyler Nilson and Michael Schwartz trafficks in the pleasure of watching intriguing people working through outlandish problems in unlikely ways. Go in expecting the best and you'll come out smiling.

title: 'The Art of Racing in the Rain' Review: Pooch Perspective
summary: In this clumsy adaptation of Garth Stein's bestselling novel, Kevin Costner voices a dog who is the cherished companion of an up-and-coming American race driver.. Maybe there's no such thing as an innately bad dog-or, who knows, maybe there is. But there are inherently bad ideas for dog movies, and one of them has just manifested itself in "The Art of Racing in the Rain."

title: Putin Plays Judo, Not Chess
summary: Russia is weak, but its leader makes the most of the West's disarray and indecisiveness.. It's been 20 years since Vladimir Putin came to power. On Aug. 9, 1999, an ailing President Boris Yeltsin anointed his successor by appointing the little-known former KGB agent as Russia's fourth prime minister in 17 months. Yeltsin declared that Mr. Putin would guarantee reforms in Russia if he won the presidential election in 2000.

title: Uber's Too Fast, Too Furious Days Could Be Ending
summary: Uber says competition will moderate, but its results say otherwise. Uber may be losing some speed, but there is plenty of power under its hood.

title: The Meaning of Mecca
summary: Some Muslims have lost touch with the reason for the annual hajj pilgrimage.. One of the largest gatherings of religious pilgrims in the world, the hajj, begins Friday in Mecca, Saudi Arabia. More than two million Muslim men, women and children will assemble to honor the prophet Abraham and his second wife, Hagar. All of them will be challenged to uphold the spirit of the hajj.

title: Going to Extremes Against Guns
summary: Threatening to take voters' firearms away isn't the way to beat Donald Trump.. Democrats insist there's no more urgent job than ensuring Donald Trump is a one-term president. Which is odd, given how hard they are simultaneously working to alienate the voters they most need to make that happen. See this week's debate on gun control.

title: Vegetarianism as Climate Virtue Signaling
summary: First World solipsism misses the point of a new U.N. report.. 'Eat Less Meat" is the typical headline used to present a new United Nations report on climate change released Thursday. The report correctly points to the need to improve global food systems, but pundits are fixating on the supposed need for people in rich countries to change their dining habits radically. This is an ineffective and unachievable policy response.

title: 'Semicolon' Review: Between a Pause and a Hard Stop
summary: The semicolon can be overused, but the language needs a punctuation mark that tells readers "Slow down, but don't stop.". Most English-speakers who write for a living have some appreciation for the semicolon, but a few dislike it or avoid it altogether. "Do not use semicolons," Kurt Vonnegut wrote. "They are transvestite hermaphrodites representing absolutely nothing. All they do is show you've been to college." Of course, you could say the same thing about the word "hermaphrodite." I am fond of the semicolon; so much so, indeed, that the books editor of this newspaper once asked me if I buy my semicolons individually or by the boxful.

title: Modi's Kashmir Gambit Puts Pakistan in a Tough Spot
summary: Islamabad has little clout, what with its support for terrorism and an economy one-eighth India's size.. One of Asia's oldest disputes reached an inflection point this week as India suddenly terminated autonomy for Jammu and Kashmir, the Muslim-majority province claimed by both India and Pakistan. The long-term implications are unclear, but one thing appears obvious already: When it comes to the seven-decade-old Kashmir conflict, Pakistan has few cards left to play.

title: A Minuscule Mob Shuts Down a Debate on Reparations
summary: 'When someone like me buckles,' admits the owner of the Comedy Cellar, 'there is blood in the water.'. It doesn't take a lot of people to form a mob. When universities cancel speeches, it's almost always in response to the demands of a tiny but loud minority. And last month New York's Comedy Cellar canceled a debate on slavery reparations in response to a puny protest.

title: Notable & Quotable: China Watches Citizens Sort Their Recycling
summary: 'Shanghai's waste sorting system adds yet another level to surveillance.'. Celine Suiwriting for the South China Morning Post, Aug. 5:

title: An American Song, an American Crisis
summary: In times like this, brave and bold experimentation is the closest we'll get to finding a solution.. Moon river wider than a mile

title: Past Performance Is No Guide for Progressives
summary: It would be an interesting exercise to examine whether either John Hickenlooper or John Delaney could have achieved what they did if the taxes, regulations and the "reforms" they suggest existed when they were making their way in the world of private business.. Regarding Kyle Peterson's "The Weekend Interview with John Hickenlooper and John Delaney: The Democrats' Capitalist Dark Horses" (July 27): It would be an interesting exercise to examine whether either could have achieved what he did if the taxes, regulations and the "reforms" they suggest existed when they were making their way in the world of private business. An even more interesting exercise would be to examine how their even more liberal rivals would fare under the proposals they have made.

title: Making Heating Carbon Free Is Complicated
summary: A new load of about twice the existing load would be added to the entire electric system, just for heating, tripling the load on the electrical system.. Regarding Richard Golomb's July 29 letter responding to your editorial "Berkeley Bans Natural Gas" (July 22): Converting building heating to renewable electric is a substantial problem. In both the Mid-Atlantic and the Upper Midwest, heating energy used by buildings is about 60% of the total energy use there, while in New England, buildings use about 64% of the total energy for heating. In the coldest weather the percentage of energy used for heat increases. On a peak New England heating day, the combined oil and gas heat would be equivalent to about 76,000 megawatts.

title: What Part Does Luck Play in Success in Life?
summary: I agree with Frayda Levin that it's annoying to hear people talk about their lives as if their choices don't matter, but I think people who argue that luck has no effect on their lives are equally annoying.. Regarding Frayda Levin's "Lady Luck Didn't Make Me Successful" (op-ed, July 27): I agree with Ms. Levin that it's annoying to hear people talk about their lives as if their choices don't matter, but I think people who argue that luck has no effect on their lives are equally annoying.

title: 'Our Boys' Review: A Chronicle of Two Crimes
summary: HBO's gripping new drama is based on the true story of the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers and the killing of a young Palestinian that followed.. It's clear from the outset of this dazzling chronicle set in Israel that there's not going to be any softening of its extraordinary tension, its scenes of anguished suffering, its furiously eloquent debates on justice and loyalty, its epic crowd scenes-tens of thousands marching to voice their rage or to pray. The ambition that powered the creation of "Our Boys" (begins Monday with back-to-back episodes, 9 p.m., HBO), a saga about two crimes and their consequences, looms over everything, a dramatic presence all its own, with each of its 10 episodes proving more complex than the last. And as a result, sharper. That so complicated, so crowded, a work of history-created and largely written by Hagai Levi, Joseph Cedar and Tawfik Abu-Wael for Keshet Studios and HBO-can emerge with the searing clarity of "Our Boys" is no small miracle of storytelling.

title: India's Modi Defends Decision to Clamp Down on Kashmir
summary: The leader says the state's special status allowed it to be used by neighboring Pakistan as a weapon. NEW DELHI-Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in his first public comments since his government's move to end the autonomy of the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir, dismissed concerns about lasting unrest after a military clampdown is lifted and said the new status would help the economy and boost the welfare of Kashmiris.

title: Newsom Out-Putins Putin
summary: How much should we worry about Russia interfering with our election?. Regarding your editorial "California Bans Trump" (Aug. 1): How much should we worry about Russia interfering with our election if we already have California Gov. Gavin Newsom rigging the ballots?

title: Bad Choices Cause Much Middle-Class Debt
summary: When I was 28 years old, I understood that I couldn't have everything I wanted "to stay in the middle class." Plus, I understood basic arithmetic.. Your article on consumer debt ("Record Debt Swamps Middle-Class Families," Page One, Aug. 2) fails to mention that the main reason the middle class is having difficulty in paying off credit-card balances is the exorbitant interest rates being assessed by the credit-card companies. During the 10-year span when the prime interest rate was at historic lows, credit-card companies were still charging interest rates of over 20% or even higher. The laws in some states, particularly South Dakota, enable credit-card companies to assess these predatory rates. Federal legislation should be passed to limit interest rates on the cards by pegging them to the consumer-price index or some comparable index, similar to what banks use in granting unsecured personal loans.

title: Kraft Heinz Writes Down $1.2 Billion as Brands Wither
summary: Food maker says further charges could follow as sales and shares fall. Kraft Heinz Co. reported falling sales and wrote down the value of its brands for the second time in six months, as the food maker struggles to improve its products to satisfy shifting consumer tastes.

title: New York Comptroller Says Better Oversight Needed for Lead Prevention
summary: Audit finds local health departments lacking in follow-up services or documentation. The New York state comptroller is calling for improved oversight of a state program that works to prevent lead poisoning and help children with elevated blood lead levels, a major health risk to children.

title: Stocks Climb as China Signals a More Stable Yuan
summary: Shares climb after a bout of market volatility; bond yields rose. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 371 points, and investors sold safe-haven assets such as bonds and gold after China's latest currency move eased concerns that its trade fight with the U.S. was about to morph into an all-out currency war.

title: Two NYC Subway Workers Save Woman
summary: Track worker signals to operator, stopping train 2 to 3 feet from woman. Two Metropolitan Transportation Authority employees saved a life, stopping a Manhattan-bound Q train just feet away from a woman who had climbed onto the tracks.

title: 'The Rainmaker' Review: Discovering an American Classic
summary: The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey stages a richly humane production of N. Richard Nash's nuanced, hopeful romantic comedy.. Madison, N.J.

title: 'Coriolanus' Review: Betraying the Bard
summary: At Shakespeare in the Park, a well-staged but ill-conceived production of Shakespeare's most explicitly political play.. New York

title: Border Arrests Dropped in July
summary: The Trump administration attributes the decrease of nearly 25% from June to closer cooperation with Mexico and Guatemala. WASHINGTON-The number of people apprehended while illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border dropped in July, according to new statistics released by the Trump administration on Thursday.

title: Homeowners Rush to Refinance, Thanks to Falling Yields
summary: Sharp drop in government-bond yields may have investors worried, but it is boosting the mortgage market. Falling bond yields have pushed mortgage rates to their lowest level in nearly three years, spurring a rush by homeowners to refinance.

title: StarKist, Facing $100 Million Fine, Says It Can't Pay
summary: A Justice Department antitrust campaign is triggering penalties and lawsuits against the three largest canned tuna producers. The U.S. government's campaign to punish StarKist Co. and other canned tuna producers for price fixing could be pushing the company's finances to the breaking point.

title: Kraft Heinz's Woes Have Shaved Almost 35% Off Market Cap This Year
summary: Ketchup maker's stock remains under heavy pressure. Investors continue to shun Kraft Heinz .

title: U.S. Government Bonds Decline After Report of German Stimulus
summary: Investors say an increase in fiscal support could help Europe's economy. U.S. government-bond prices fell Thursday after a report that the German officials are considering a fiscal stimulus package.

title: New Theater Festival Fuels Young Hope
summary: Manhattan preteen debuts musical about challenges facing child performers. It is hard work breaking into the theater scene in New York-and even harder for young people.

title: Nickel Jumps on Indonesian Export Ban Report
summary: Metal has risen over 50% this year, making it one of the best-performing commodities globally. Nickel prices on the London Metal Exchange notched their highest close in over a year on Thursday, surging more than 7% on media reports about a ban on ore exports in Indonesia.

title: Italian Populist Moves to Bring Down Government
summary: Matteo Salvini, head of nativist League, returns from the beach to press for snap elections. ROME-Matteo Salvini, head of Italy's far-right, sought to trigger snap elections by declaring an end to the government in which he serves, exploiting his strong lead in opinion polls in a bid to make himself the country's next leader.

title: Adidas Warns on Threat of U.S.-China Trade War
summary: Sporting-goods company beats analysts' expectations with robust profit growth. BERLIN- Adidas AG posted higher quarterly earnings on strong sales in China and predicted continued growth in the second half, but the German sportswear company warned that a protracted trade and currency war could derail the global economy and hurt business.

title: Swing-Seat Republican Unswayed by Pressure on Guns
summary: In the wake of the El Paso and Dayton shootings, Rep. Don Bacon, like many GOP colleagues, maintains his opposition to most new gun laws. WATERLOO, Neb.-Rep. Don Bacon fielded questions on his stance on gun-control legislation here in an overflowing room in the back of a sports bar, and the loudest cheers for the swing-seat Republican were when he stated his opposition.

title: Oil Rebounds From Near 2019 Lows
summary: A pause in U.S.-China hostilities is helping to drive crude's recovery. Crude prices rallied Thursday from near their lows for the year as investors' anxiety about global growth prospects showed signs of easing.

title: Why You Should Spend the Rest of the Summer Grilling Potatoes
summary: Baked potatoes really are the ideal barbecue guest: highly appealing, utterly undemanding. Cooking them on the grill frees you from a steamy kitchen, and the filling options are infinite. LIKE WOOLLY socks and puffy parkas, baked potatoes are usually considered cold-weather comforts. This miffs me, a cook who'd make potatoes my desert-island staple.

title: Justin Williams Can't Stop Winning Bike Races
summary: A former U.S. cycling phenom finds success-and happiness-by starting an innovative domestic team. Justin Williams kept his newest stars and stripes jersey hanging in his bedroom for a few days. Before trying it on, he wanted to look at it, admire it, take it in, what it all meant.

title: Climate Experts Advise Eating More Vegetables, Less Meat
summary: After issuing a new report detailing farming's contribution to warming, researchers suggested diet changes to reduce the impact. Climate experts meeting in Geneva recommended changes to the foods people eat and farm in an effort to stave off the disruptive effects of rising global temperatures, while growers and major food producers attempt to adapt.

title: Zillow, We Have a Problem
summary: Zillow's long-term business transformation is ambitious, but the third-quarter outlook has some investors jumping ship. Zillow Chief Executive Rich Barton doesn't think small. In a conference call for investors Wednesday, he likened the company's disruption of the real estate industry to landing the first man on the moon.

title: How Do You Make a $200k Bentley Truly Yours? Spend More
summary: The redesigned Bentley Continental GT is your basic $200k super-luxe aphrodisiac that goes 0-60 in as fast as 3.3 seconds, says Dan Neil. And the more cash you lay out, the better it gets. IN THESE UNCERTAIN times it's comforting to know that a quarter-million dollars still buys a lot of automobile.

title: U.K. Fraud Agency Strikes New Tone With Cooperation Guidance
summary: The Serious Fraud Office's guidance on how companies should cooperate with investigators could revive tensions with lawyers over legal privilege. Companies looking for lenient treatment by U.K.'s major economic crimes investigator now have a road map-albeit one that comes with few promises.

title: It Is Tricky Finding Safety From a Market Storm
summary: The next big market scare might not be far away, but is hard to prepare for. The bond market is holding up a giant sign in capital letters warning of trouble ahead. Investors are on edge. The next big market scare might not be far away, but is hard to prepare for.

title: Treasury to Sell $112 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department next week will auction 13-week, 26-week and 52-week bills. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $112 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: China Exports Stage Surprising Turnaround
summary: An increase in shipments to Europe and Southeast Asia helped rebound, but economists expect trend to be short-lived. BEIJING-Chinese exports rebounded in July, buoyed by increased shipments to Europe and Southeast Asia, but economists expect the turnaround to be short-lived as Beijing and Washington escalate their trade battle.

title: How 'Red, White & Royal Blue' Became the Unlikely Book of the Summer
summary: It's a book that blends 'Veep,' 'Parks & Recreation' and a queer '10 Things I Hate About You'-and became a surprise bestseller. How the juggernaut novel spread to every beach blanket. In the spring of 2016, writer Casey McQuiston, then 25 years old, was driving on the I-10 highway in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, when an idea for a novel came to her. Then came the presidential election. The Louisiana native, now 28, says she had to quickly "grapple with a world that was [now] different than we thought it was." So she set her book aside for eight months. After a trip to Norway, away from news back home, she picked it up again and finished a first draft about six months later. The result is Red, White & Royal Blue, a romantic comic novel about political figures that became an unlikely New York Times bestseller.

title: Who Moved Kraft Heinz's Cheese?
summary: The food company's shares fell sharply after it reported sliding sales, but challenges are hardly over. The best thing that can be said about Kraft Heinz's results on Thursday is that it was only the second worst day of 2019 for the sprawling food company-so far, at least.

title: The Man Who Turned the U.S. Into a Circus
summary: P.T. Barnum pioneered the arts of celebrity, scandal and spectacle that continue to shape our culture today. The three-ring circus aspect of modern life had to start somewhere. All the hustle and bustle that fills our days-the social-media imperative to create a persona and tirelessly promote it, the confusing welter of information both legitimate and illegitimate to which we are exposed, the naked power of advertising to create desires in us we didn't know we had-cannot be traced to a single source. But some people are more responsible than others.

title: Why Zozo's Plan to Sell Clothes That Fit Perfectly Didn't Work Out
summary: Resume Subscription. Zozo Inc.'s Yusaku Maezawa became a billionaire with Zozotown, a fashion website that dominates online clothing sales in Japan, selling more than 7,000 brands and catering to young, fashion-forward customers. He attracted international attention when he spent $110.5 million in 2017 on a Jean-Michel Basquiat painting of a black skull, and he bought the first ticket to travel to the moon in 2023 with Elon Musk's SpaceX.

title: Viacom Improves Performance as CBS Merger Talks Continue
summary: The company grew its domestic advertising revenue for the first time in 20 quarters and posted growth at its filmed-entertainment division. Viacom Inc. posted revenue growth thanks to its first uptick in domestic advertising in 20 quarters, a sign that the media giant's performance is improving after a prolonged slump.

title: Beautiful Scraps: Luxury Design Objects That Started as Leftovers
summary: Design companies, including Hermès, are transforming bits of materials left over in their manufacturing processes into covetable trays, glasses and more. WHEN COMPANIES that deal in high-end materials have leftovers, the prospect of tossing those remnants into a steamy landfill understandably pains them. Repurposing those bits and bobs saves manufacturers agony (read: cash) and lets on-a-budget aesthetes sample luxury for less.

title: Do Men And Women Really Need Different Skin Care?
summary: Some experts argue that men's and women's skin types differ enough to warrant separate product lines. Others dismiss that as a tired, old-school approach. ONE-SIZE-FITS-ALL doesn't work for basic T-shirts, so how could it ever work for something as personal as skin care? "Men and women have similarities in their skin-but differences as well," said New York dermatologist Rachel Nazarian. Men tend to have thicker, oily skin and denser hair growth while women have less fuzz but thinner, drier skin. These variables, said Dr. Nazarian, "can make the need for different products necessary."

title: Tiny Roku Fends Off Amazon and Thrives by Selling Ads
summary: The Los Gatos, Calif., firm has carved out a lucrative niche in the world of streaming video despite competing against tech giants. Roku Inc. is tiny compared with the tech and telecom giants spending billions to compete in the streaming-video world, but its stock has more than tripled since Christmas on the growing popularity of internet videos.

title: More People Are Working Remotely. That Means Unexpected Guests On Video Calls.
summary: Telecommuters come up with strategies to avoid embarrassment and keep toddlers, chatty parents and the occasional monkey out of their work meetings. At first, Tom Trahan thought it was just a very casual Friday.

title: Through a Glass, Darkly, at McDonald's
summary: McDonald's Japan is red-faced after releasing cups aimed at children that have lewd images when held a certain way. The owner of the golden arches tries to cultivate a wholesome image-not just in its home country but abroad as well. An attempt to do that at McDonald's in Japan has failed spectacularly, but it has been a commercial success, proving once again that "sex sells."

title: AT&T, CBS Resolve Distribution-Fee Dispute
summary: A blackout affected 26 stations in 17 markets, including New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. AT&T Inc. and CBS Corp. have reached an agreement that will bring back CBS offerings to about 6.6 million AT&T customers who lost access to local TV news channels because of a distribution-fee dispute.

title: Finding the Magic in Liquid Crystals
summary: The uncanny material in your TV display may hold astonishing potential for creating future technologies. The most glamorous fields in physics are probably cosmology and the search for new fundamental laws. While those subjects are glorious, there's also another frontier to relish: the pursuit of magic. Of course, here I don't mean trickery but magic in the spirit of the science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke's famous law: "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic."

title: A Look at Gun Proposals and Their Potential to Curb Shootings
summary: Universal background checks, banning assault weapons and red-flag laws are among measures being proposed. The killings of more than 30 people in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas, have renewed debate in Washington over how much any of the leading proposals to change gun laws would do to prevent mass shootings.

title: To Combat 'Deepfakes,' Researchers Turn to Mice
summary: Rodents can be trained to distinguish between real and computerized speech, data scientists show. LAS VEGAS-Dogs are commonly called man's best friend, but when it comes to determining whether voice recordings are real or fake, mice might be a better ally.

title: 'Screed': From a Scrap of Paper to a Lengthy Message of Hate
summary: A term used to describe violent diatribes once referred to shreds of material, until it was influenced by 'scream' and 'shriek'. When the news broke on Sunday that the man accused of a mass shooting in El Paso had posted a piece of writing online shortly before the shooting occurred, one immediate question for journalists was what to call that writing, which was filled with hateful opinions about a supposed "Hispanic invasion of Texas."

title: This Tuscan Villa Comes With 40 Rooms and a $60 Million Price Tag
summary: The sprawling 21,000-square-foot home, which has ties to the Machiavelli family, is a relic of Florence's Golden Age. Nestled in the Tuscan hills at the end of a road lined with cypress trees sits Villa Poggio Torselli, a Renaissance-era mansion surrounded by vineyards and expansive English-style gardens.

title: After El Paso Shooting, Workers Plot Their Own 'What-If' Escape Plans
summary: Insect spray, homemade panic buttons and walk-in freezers serve as contingency plans in case of workplace attacks. Like many U.S. workers lately, Maricarmen Molina has mentally mapped out how she hopes to escape should a gunman ever enter her workplace.

title: Live Like a Machiavelli
summary: Inside a grand Tuscan estate for sale outside Florence.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: What Huntsman's Return to Utah Will Reveal About GOP Politics
summary: The departing U.S. ambassador to Russia is likely to receive a warm welcome in his home state despite his ties to Obama and Trump. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: The A-Frame Home Becomes a Thing Again
summary: This unique architectural style is angling for a comeback, thanks to the tiny-home movement and a renewed appreciation for the triangular form. Few American home silhouettes are as immediately recognizable as the classic A-frame, with its steep pitched roof that extends down to or near the foundation.

title: Economists See Greater Chance of September Rate Cut: WSJ Survey
summary: Chance of a recession in the next year also goes up, economists say. Economists' expectations for a September Federal Reserve rate cut rose sharply this month, along with their expectations for a recession in the next year.

title: Economists Upgrade U.S.-China Trade Conflict to 'War'
summary: In a WSJ survey, 87% of respondents say it's a 'trade war,' up from 50% a year ago. The economic consensus is in: The U.S. and China are in a trade war.

title: Facebook Tests Selling Video Subscriptions in Watch

title: NYSE Antennas Spark High-Speed Trader Backlash
summary: Setup expected to give the exchange's affiliated network provider exclusive access, and traders fear having to pay hefty fees for use. TEL AVIV-An off-duty Israeli soldier was found stabbed to death near a West Bank settlement early Thursday, prompting a manhunt for the killer in what the Israeli military called a terrorist attack.

title: Hong Kong Police Draw Protester Rage, but Beijing Doesn't Think They're Tough Enough
summary: Force becomes a local target while China presses them to restore order. HONG KONG-With Hong Kong's summer of unrest escalating, its police are in a bind. The local population increasingly accuses them of inflaming protester rage by using excessive force, while mainland Chinese authorities are exhorting them to get tougher to resolve the crisis.

summary: The company uses AI software to comb through its workers' comp data to identify overprescribing doctors. Every day, Hartford Financial Services GroupInc. uses artificial-intelligence software to scan its files of workers' compensation cases for people at risk of opioid addiction.

summary: State Department asks visitors to exercise increased caution, citing protests; tourism arrivals down 31% in early August. HONG KONG-The U.S. raised the level of its advisory for citizens traveling to Hong Kong, asking them to exercise increased caution and citing nearly two months of protests that have bitten into the city's tourism.

title: When Napa Valley Cuisine Goes to China
summary: Michelin-starred American chef Christopher Kostow has been challenged to put Shenzhen, China, on the global culinary map. But first he has to learn how the locals take their soup. "In every industry, people have their eyes on China," says chef Christopher Kostow. "Everyone wants to sell in China, everyone wants a Chinese audience. This is where everything is happening." Ambition aside, Kostow has learned that wanting to be in China and being ready for China are two distinctly different things.

title: Police Launch 8chan Probe in Philippines
summary: Investigators look for any negligence in moderation of site linked to U.S. mass shootings. Police in the Philippines said they had opened an investigation into 8chan, an online message board whose American owner lives in the country, following allegations that the site's no-exceptions embrace of free speech has made it a platform for far-right ideologies linked to several mass shootings.

title: Mexican Inflation Eased in July to Lowest Since 2016
summary: CPI rose 0.38%, bringing the annual inflation rate down to 3.78%. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's inflation rate eased in July as lower energy costs partially offset moderate increases in prices of other goods and services.

title: Mozambique Sues Mogul in London Court Over Loan Deal
summary: Lawsuit is the latest in a series of criminal and civil cases centered around $2 billion in loans. Mozambique is suing Lebanese-French businessman Iskander Safa for fraud in a U.K. court, opening a new front in the country's efforts to rid itself of $2 billion in debt raised by state-owned companies to buy fishing boats and other products from Mr. Safa's company, Privinvest Group.

title: In Gulf Tanker Crisis, Iran Tries to Avoid Alienating Allies
summary: Indian crews and China-bound oil are caught up in Tehran's retaliation over Trump administration's sanctions. Iran's disruptions of Persian Gulf oil shipments are putting the country's leaders in a difficult position as they retaliate against foes while trying not to irritate their few remaining allies.

title: A Regular Guy Threw 96 MPH. A Viral Video Turned Him Into a Prospect.
summary: Nathan Patterson was a software salesman killing time during a rain delay. He's now one of the unlikeliest professional baseball players in history.. During a rain delay at a Colorado Rockies game last month, Nathan Patterson tried his luck at a speed-pitch challenge booth. The first ball he fired reached 90 mph. The next two, 94. On his sixth and final attempt, the screen behind him lit up with an even gaudier number: 96.

title: To Really Learn, Our Children Need the Power of Play
summary: The U.S. can learn a big lesson from Finland's education system: Instead of stress and standardized testing, schools should focus on well-being and joy. Five years ago, we switched countries.

title: Emerging-Market Stocks Correct Sharply as Trade Battle Flares
summary: The MSCI Emerging Markets Index is down 11% from its recent highs, putting it in correction territory. Investors are fleeing emerging-market stocks and currencies, fearful that an escalating trade war between the U.S. and China will weigh on global growth.

summary: Alternative data that evaluate creditworthiness are gaining traction, but policy makers grapple with fairness issues. WASHINGTON-Should borrowers be denied new loans because they didn't finish college?

summary: Some documents are related to Russians who may have had dealings with Mr. Trump, his family or Trump Organization.

title: What to Buy in Mumbai? 4 Memorable Suggestions
summary: From eye-popping earrings to vintage-style posters, where to shop for modern swag in the Indian megalopolis. The homegrown brand of Nicobar and its three breezy shops in Mumbai embody a contemporary, keenly Indian approach to lifestyle. Think minimalist linens and tableware with tropical motifs and feather-light cotton tunics. There's plenty for the guys, too: Pick up this olive weekender jacket that looks sharp and travels well to boot. $108, available at Nicobar stores; nicobar.com.

title: How Hong Kong Can Save Itself
summary: Maintaining the city's position as a global financial powerhouse requires a resolution to the political stalemate and an economic overhaul. Hong Kong is in the midst of its worst political violence since the semiautonomous city's handover to China in 1997. Defusing the crisis-and maintaining its status as a global financial powerhouse and conduit for capital into China-requires urgent action not only on grievances including police accountability and stalled electoral reforms but also on deep, festering problems with the city's economic model.

title: AI Is Hot and SoftBank Is Offering Cash to Burn
summary: Vision Fund 2 is targeted to be more than five times the $20 billion raised by privately backed AI companies globally in 2018. SoftBank Group Corp.'s plans for a second technology megafund focused on artificial-intelligence startups is poised to flood an already-hyped sector with more cash as skepticism mounts about investor exuberance for such companies.

title: Australian Lawmaker Compares China's Rise to Nazi Germany's
summary: The staunch U.S. ally walks a fine line with China as its biggest trading partner. CANBERRA, Australia-An influential Australian lawmaker has likened China's rise to that of Nazi Germany, in comments that risk exacerbating tensions with Beijing and underscore the U.S. ally's challenge in balancing security ties with America and relations with its most important trade partner.

title: Trump Says He Is Weighing Commuting Sentence of Blagojevich
summary: Former Illinois governor was convicted of corruption charges, once appeared on 'Celebrity Apprentice'. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Wednesday said he is considering commuting the sentence of former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich.

title: China's Official Yuan Rate Crosses 7-Per-Dollar Milestone
summary: It was the lowest level since 2008. China set a daily anchor for trading in its currency at the weakest level since 2008 on Thursday, crossing the symbolic 7-per-dollar threshold that the central bank had already allowed markets to breach earlier this week.

title: Venezuela Withdraws From Planned Talks With Opposition
summary: President Nicolás Maduro cancels Norway-brokered negotiations this week. Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro pulled his government out of negotiations with the opposition aimed at resolving the country's political crisis after the Trump administration imposed sweeping sanctions against the authoritarian regime.

title: Illinois Colleges Urge Lawmakers to Close Financial-Aid Loophole
summary: Wealthy and middle-class parents transfer guardianship of children to qualify for more financial aid. CHICAGO-Illinois educators urged state lawmakers to close a college financial-aid loophole by which affluent and middle-class parents have transferred guardianship of their children to tap programs intended for low-income families.

title: Trump Visits Grieving Cities as Gun-Control Debate Boils
summary: Democrats pressed for action, while Trump blasted those who said his language helped sow division, violence. President Trump met with victims of mass shootings in Ohio and Texas on a trip designed to offer comfort during a moment of national mourning, but his visits were punctuated by fights with Democrats angered by his rhetoric and skeptical of his pledge to tackle gun violence.

title: Leslie Wexner Says Jeffrey Epstein Misappropriated 'Vast Sums' From Him
summary: Leslie Wexner, in letter to foundation, said the amount was at least $46 million. Leslie Wexner, the billionaire behind Victoria's Secret, said his former money manager Jeffrey Epstein misappropriated more than $46 million of his fortune, revealing for the first time some of the financial fallout from his relationship with the disgraced financier.

title: Universal Pictures Halts Marketing of 'The Hunt' After Mass Shootings
summary: Comcast unit is pausing its ad campaign for 'The Hunt,' due in September, and reviewing materials. Comcast Corp.'s Universal Pictures is postponing marketing of a coming thriller about Americans hunting fellow Americans out of concern the violent film's ad campaign is too reminiscent of mass shootings in the past week.

title: Huntsman to Sell Two Units for $2.1 Billion
summary: Asian rival Indorama Ventures Deal to acquire chemical intermediates and surfactants businesses. Chemicals maker Huntsman Corp. agreed to sell two units to an Asian rival for roughly $2.1 billion.

title: Medicare Moves to Cover Costly Cell Therapies
summary: Hospitals can get reimbursement for at least 65% of the costs of CAR-T therapies and related treatment. Medicare and Medicaid will cover an expensive new kind of cancer drug and related services, though the federal government insurance programs won't pay 100% of the costs, which can approach $1 million a patient.

title: Report Cites Trump Policy Decisions in Signs of Islamic State Comeback
summary: Extremist group's determination, difficulties encountered by U.S.- backed forces are noted. Islamic State militants are strengthening their capability to carry out insurgent attacks in Iraq and Syria, according to a new report to Congress by the Pentagon's Office of Inspector General that in part links Trump administration policy decisions to signs of a resurgence.

title: What Falling Interest Rates Mean for You
summary: A decrease in interest rates affects everything from mortgages to student loans. Long-term interest rates are falling fast in the U.S. The 10-year Treasury dropped to 1.6% at one point Wednesday. It started the year around 2.7%.
